demographics: 34-year-old woman, married, works as an elementary school teacher, lives with spouse and one child. No prior psychiatric hospitalizations. Occasional social alcohol use (1–2 drinks/month), denies tobacco and illicit substances.
clinical_text:
Ms. A is a 34-year-old elementary school teacher presenting for evaluation due to 6 weeks of progressively worsening low mood and functional decline. She reports feeling "sad and heavy all day, nearly every day" and says that even when she tries to distract herself, "it doesn’t lift." She describes marked loss of interest in activities she previously enjoyed (reading novels, jogging, and playing with her child): "I used to look forward to weekends—now I just want to stay in bed." She notes significant fatigue: "I’m exhausted no matter how much I rest." 

She endorses insomnia with early-morning awakening for the past month, typically waking around 3–4 a.m. and being unable to return to sleep. She reports decreased appetite with an unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the last 5–6 weeks. She describes psychomotor slowing observed by others: "My husband says I move like I’m in slow motion," and she feels it takes great effort to complete routine tasks such as showering and preparing lessons.

Cognitively, she reports poor concentration and indecisiveness at work: "I read the same email three times and it still doesn’t register." She has missed multiple deadlines, has called in sick twice in the last two weeks, and worries she is "letting the kids down." She endorses excessive guilt and feelings of worthlessness disproportionate to events: "I feel like a terrible mom and a failure as a teacher," despite colleagues telling her she is usually reliable and effective.

She acknowledges recurrent thoughts of death and passive suicidal ideation: "Sometimes I think it would be easier if I just didn’t wake up." Over the past week, she has had intermittent thoughts of "ending it" but denies a specific plan or intent, stating, "I don’t want to hurt my family." She denies access to firearms and denies prior suicide attempts. She denies hallucinations, delusional beliefs, or paranoia.

There is no history of periods of abnormally elevated or expansive mood, decreased need for sleep with increased energy, pressured speech, racing thoughts, increased goal-directed activity, impulsive spending, or other episodes suggestive of mania or hypomania. She denies recent substance use changes, including stimulants or steroids. She denies recent bereavement; she identifies no single triggering event, though she reports chronic work stress. Medical history is unremarkable; she denies thyroid disease, recent infections, or neurologic symptoms. Current medications include only an oral contraceptive; she is not taking over-the-counter weight-loss agents or supplements. Family history is notable for a mother with recurrent depressive episodes.

On mental status examination, she appears tired and mildly disheveled, with slowed movements. Speech is soft and slowed but coherent. Mood is "down"; affect is constricted and tearful at times. Thought process is linear. Thought content is notable for guilt, hopelessness, and passive suicidal ideation without plan or intent. No homicidal ideation. Cognition is grossly intact, but attention is reduced. Insight and judgment are fair. Symptoms have been present most days for more than two weeks and are causing clinically significant distress and impairment in occupational performance and family functioning.

demographics: 34-year-old woman, married, works full-time as a project manager at a marketing firm, lives with spouse and one child. No prior psychiatric hospitalizations. Drinks 1–2 cups of coffee daily, rare alcohol use, denies tobacco or illicit substances.
clinical_text:
Ms. L is a 34-year-old project manager who presents for evaluation of persistent anxiety and worry that she describes as "constant" and "hard to shut off" for the past 9–10 months. She reports excessive worry occurring on most days about multiple areas of life, including job performance and deadlines, her child's health and safety, finances, and the possibility of making mistakes or disappointing others. She states, "Even when things are fine, my brain finds something else to worry about." She reports difficulty controlling the worry, noting that reassurance and checking provide only brief relief before the worry returns.

Associated symptoms include feeling keyed up and restless ("I’m on edge all the time"), easy fatigability (she feels mentally and physically drained by mid-afternoon), difficulty concentrating ("I read the same email three times and still miss things"), irritability (snapping at her spouse and coworkers), muscle tension (tight neck/shoulders with frequent jaw clenching), and sleep disturbance (trouble falling asleep due to ruminative thoughts and waking early with worry). She reports these symptoms have been present for months and occur on most days.

She describes functional impairment: she spends excessive time rechecking work, has missed deadlines due to over-preparing, avoids delegating tasks, and feels less effective at work. At home, she reports being "short-tempered" and less present with her child, and she has reduced social activities because "I can’t relax and I’m too tired." She denies panic attacks, obsessions/compulsions, trauma-related flashbacks/nightmares, or specific social-performance fears as the primary driver of symptoms. She endorses occasional GI upset when anxious but no significant weight loss or gain.

Mood is described as "stressed and overwhelmed"; she denies persistent depressed mood or anhedonia as primary symptoms. She denies current or past manic/hypomanic episodes (no periods of abnormally elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, pressured speech, or risky behavior). She denies hallucinations, delusions, or disorganized thinking. She denies suicidal or homicidal ideation.

Medical history is unremarkable aside from episodic tension headaches. She is not taking stimulants, steroids, or thyroid medication. She denies increased alcohol use and denies cannabis or other substances. Recent primary care visit reportedly included normal thyroid testing and basic labs. No evidence of a medical condition or substance effect explaining the anxiety.

Mental status examination: well-groomed, cooperative, mildly fidgety. Speech normal rate and volume. Affect anxious and congruent. Thought process linear but preoccupied with "what if" concerns. No psychosis. Cognition grossly intact though attention is subjectively impaired by worry. Insight and judgment fair.

Overall presentation is notable for excessive, difficult-to-control worry across multiple domains occurring more days than not for >6 months, accompanied by multiple physical/cognitive symptoms and causing clinically significant distress and impairment.

demographics: 29-year-old man, software project coordinator at a mid-sized tech company; lives with partner; college graduate.
clinical_text:
Chief concern: “I can’t stay on track—I start things and then my brain jumps somewhere else.”

History of present illness: The patient reports a long-standing pattern of distractibility, disorganization, and restlessness that has become more impairing in his current role coordinating multiple projects with frequent deadlines. He describes making “careless mistakes” in emails and scheduling (e.g., wrong dates, missing key details), despite understanding the tasks. He reports difficulty sustaining attention during meetings and while reading documentation: “I’ll read the same paragraph five times and still not absorb it.” He frequently “tunes out” in conversations, stating his partner will say, “You’re not listening,” and he realizes he missed what was said.

He endorses difficulty following through on tasks: he starts drafting plans or updating trackers but leaves items unfinished, especially when tasks require sustained mental effort. He reports chronic disorganization (messy workspace, scattered notes across apps, missed action items), poor time management, and underestimating how long tasks will take. He avoids or procrastinates on tasks requiring prolonged focus (e.g., budget reviews, long reports), describing them as “painful to start.” He frequently loses items needed for tasks (badge, earbuds, charging cables, keys) and relies heavily on reminders; even so, he forgets obligations such as appointments and responding to messages. He is easily distracted by notifications and background activity: “If someone walks by or Slack pings, I’m gone.”

In addition, he describes prominent restlessness and impulsive behaviors. He fidgets, taps his foot, and shifts in his chair throughout the interview. He reports feeling internally “driven” and has difficulty staying seated through long meetings, often standing or pacing. He talks more than he intends to and catches himself interrupting: “I blurt things out before people finish.” He has trouble waiting his turn in discussions and will interject or complete others’ sentences, later regretting it. He describes impatience in lines and while driving, though he denies road rage, accidents, or reckless speeding.

Course and onset: Symptoms began in childhood and were present before age 12. He recalls frequent teacher comments such as “bright but doesn’t apply himself,” “daydreams,” and “talks too much.” He often forgot to turn in homework he had completed, lost school supplies, and needed repeated reminders to finish chores. He reports academic performance was inconsistent—doing well on subjects he found interesting but struggling with sustained reading and longer assignments. His mother (contacted with his permission) corroborates longstanding patterns of forgetfulness, losing items, interrupting, and needing constant prompting to stay on task.

Settings and impairment: Symptoms occur across multiple settings (work, home, and social situations). At work, he has received feedback about missed details, late follow-through, and “seeming distracted” in meetings. He has been placed on a performance improvement plan due to deadline slippage and incomplete documentation. At home, his partner reports he forgets shared plans, leaves chores half-finished, and appears not to listen, leading to conflict. Socially, friends comment that he dominates conversations, changes topics abruptly, and interrupts.

Compensatory strategies: He uses multiple calendars, alarms, and sticky notes and has tried productivity apps; these help briefly but he struggles to maintain systems consistently. He drinks 1–2 coffees daily and denies use of illicit stimulants.

Psychiatric review: He denies episodes of elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, grandiosity, or increased goal-directed activity suggestive of mania/hypomania. He denies persistent depressed mood or anhedonia; he reports situational stress and frustration related to performance but no sustained depressive syndrome. He denies panic attacks, intrusive obsessions/compulsions, trauma-related flashbacks, hallucinations, or delusions. He denies current suicidal or homicidal ideation.

Medical/substance history: No history of seizures or significant head injury. Sleep is 6–7 hours/night; he reports difficulty “shutting off” thoughts at bedtime on some nights but no chronic insomnia. Alcohol: 1–2 drinks on weekends; denies blackouts. Denies tobacco, cannabis, or other substances. No current medications.

Mental status exam (brief): Alert and oriented; cooperative. Speech normal rate/volume, occasionally rapid when excited. Mood “stressed”; affect congruent. Thought process generally linear but tangential at times, requiring redirection. No psychosis. Attention is variable; he requests repetition of questions and is easily pulled by noises in the hallway. Insight and judgment intact.

Clinical impression: The presentation reflects a persistent pattern of inattention and hyperactive/impulsive behaviors with childhood onset, present across settings, causing clear functional impairment, and not better accounted for by another psychiatric or medical condition based on the history provided.

demographics: 32-year-old woman, married, works as an emergency department nurse, no prior psychiatric history, no substance use disorder; occasional social alcohol (1–2 drinks/week).
clinical_text:
A 32-year-old emergency department nurse presents for evaluation of persistent anxiety, sleep disturbance, and functional decline following a traumatic workplace event. Eight months ago, she was involved in a mass-casualty incident in which multiple critically injured patients arrived simultaneously; she reports directly witnessing severe injuries and death, including performing prolonged resuscitation efforts on a teenager who died despite intervention. She states, “I can still see his face when I close my eyes. I smell the blood sometimes like it’s happening again.”

Since the event, she describes recurrent, involuntary, and distressing memories occurring “multiple times a day,” with vivid mental images and sensory details. She endorses nightmares 3–5 nights per week about “being trapped in the trauma bay and nobody can hear me,” waking in a panic and drenched in sweat. She reports episodes at work where she briefly feels as if the event is recurring: “When the ambulance doors open and I hear the monitor alarms, it’s like I’m back there. My body reacts before my brain catches up.” During these episodes she experiences intense fear, palpitations, shaking, and shortness of breath. She reports marked distress and physiological reactivity when exposed to reminders such as sirens, monitor beeps, the smell of antiseptic, or seeing teenagers in the ED: “My heart starts racing and I have to fight the urge to run out.”

She reports persistent avoidance of reminders. She has switched from trauma-bay shifts to a lower-acuity area and calls in sick when she anticipates high-volume nights. She avoids driving past the site of the incident staging area and refuses to watch news coverage of accidents or violence. She also avoids discussing the event with coworkers and family: “If I start talking about it, I feel like I’m going to lose control, so I shut it down.”

She describes negative changes in mood and thinking that began after the incident. She reports persistent guilt and self-blame: “I keep thinking I should have done more… I must have missed something.” She endorses a persistent negative emotional state with fear, shame, and anger, describing herself as “on edge and numb at the same time.” She reports diminished interest in previously enjoyable activities (stopped running with friends and rarely plays with her dog), emotional detachment from her spouse (“I’m just not there; I feel disconnected”), and an inability to experience positive emotions: “Even when something good happens, I can’t feel happy—just flat.” She denies persistent depressive symptoms predating the event and denies current suicidal ideation, intent, or plan.

She also reports increased arousal and reactivity: difficulty falling asleep and frequent awakenings, irritability with verbal outbursts (“I snap at my husband over nothing”), hypervigilance in public places (“I scan exits in restaurants and can’t sit with my back to the door”), an exaggerated startle response to sudden noises, and problems with concentration (“I reread the same chart three times and still can’t focus”). She denies reckless or self-destructive behaviors.

Symptoms have been present for more than six months, occurring most days, and have caused clinically significant distress and impairment. She reports decreased work performance, increased sick days, and conflict in her marriage. She is not taking any new medications, denies illicit drug use, and reports no recent increase in alcohol intake. There is no history suggestive of a primary psychotic disorder or manic episode; she recognizes that the intrusive experiences are related to the traumatic event and does not endorse fixed delusional beliefs. No acute medical issues are reported that would better explain the symptoms.

demographics: 29-year-old woman, software QA analyst at a mid-sized tech company; lives alone; completed a bachelor's degree in computer science; no current substance use; limited social network; no prior psychiatric hospitalizations.
clinical_text:
Chief concern: "I think I have anxiety. I keep rehearsing conversations and I feel on edge at work."

History of present illness: The patient presents for evaluation at the urging of her manager after several workplace conflicts and increasing distress during team meetings. She reports episodes she labels as "anxiety" that intensify in situations involving unstructured social expectations (e.g., informal discussions, office celebrations, sudden changes in meeting agendas) and in environments with high sensory load (open-plan office noise, fluorescent lighting). She describes feeling tense and preoccupied before meetings, stating, "If I don’t know exactly what I’m supposed to say, my brain freezes," and "I’m worried I’ll miss a cue and everyone will think I’m rude." The preoccupation is described as focused on predicting specific social outcomes and preventing misunderstandings rather than multiple unrelated life domains. She denies persistent, free-floating worry about finances, health, world events, or a wide range of everyday matters. She also denies that the worry feels globally uncontrollable; instead she reports it decreases significantly when she is given written agendas, explicit role expectations, or remote participation options.

She reports a lifelong pattern of difficulty interpreting others’ intentions unless stated directly: "I don’t pick up hints," and "People say I’m blunt, but I’m just being accurate." She describes challenges with back-and-forth conversation, noting she can speak at length about preferred topics but struggles to notice when others are disengaged: "If someone asks about bugs in the build, I can explain for 20 minutes. Later I realize they just wanted a yes/no." In friendships and dating, she reports misreading sarcasm, difficulty with small talk, and uncertainty about relationship boundaries; she maintains one close friend from college with whom she mostly communicates by text.

Behavioral patterns and interests: She reports strong preferences for predictability and routines, including eating the same breakfast daily and arranging her workspace in a specific order; she becomes distressed by unexpected changes, describing "a spike of panic" when meetings are moved without notice. She describes time-consuming, highly focused interests in train timetables and data visualization, stating she can spend hours organizing information "because it feels calming and makes sense." She notes repetitive self-soothing behaviors under stress, including rocking slightly in her chair and rubbing her fingertips together; she attempts to suppress these at work to avoid comments.

Sensory features: She reports longstanding sensitivity to sound and tactile stimuli. She avoids crowded restaurants due to overlapping conversations and clattering dishes, describing it as "painful" and leading to irritability and shutdown. She prefers specific clothing fabrics and removes tags due to discomfort. At the office, she uses noise-canceling headphones and asks to dim her monitor brightness; she reports headaches and fatigue after days with heavy in-person interaction.

Developmental history: When asked about childhood, she reports being "the quiet kid" who preferred solitary play and organizing objects. Her mother (contacted with patient permission) recalls she spoke early but "talked like a little professor," corrected adults, and had intense, narrow interests (memorizing transit maps). She had difficulty with peer play, often "lecturing" or insisting on specific rules; she was teased for being "weird" and tended to eat lunch alone. She had notable distress with transitions (e.g., substitute teachers, schedule changes) and frequent meltdowns at home after school that the family attributed to being "overwhelmed." No history of language delay requiring intervention was reported, though pragmatic communication difficulties were noted.

Current functioning and impairment: At work, she is technically strong but receives feedback about communication style, rigidity, and difficulty adapting to shifting priorities. She reports exhaustion after masking and increased sick days following days with high social demands. In daily life, she manages independent living but relies on strict routines for shopping and chores, and becomes overwhelmed in unfamiliar settings. She reports sleep is generally adequate unless a major change is expected; on those nights she has difficulty initiating sleep due to mentally reviewing the upcoming interaction.

Anxiety-related symptoms and differential considerations: She endorses somatic tension, restlessness, and occasional nausea before socially demanding or sensory-heavy events. These symptoms are situation-linked and improve with environmental accommodations, clear instructions, and predictable schedules. She denies chronic, excessive worry occurring more days than not about numerous areas of life. She does not report panic attacks that occur unexpectedly; episodes are reliably triggered by specific contexts (crowded spaces, ambiguous social tasks, sudden changes). She denies compulsions aimed at neutralizing intrusive thoughts, and denies intrusive ego-dystonic thoughts. She denies depressed mood most days, anhedonia, or suicidal ideation. She reports occasional irritability and shutdown when overstimulated, followed by relief when in a quiet space.

Mental status exam: Well-groomed, cooperative. Eye contact intermittent and often directed away while thinking. Speech fluent with formal phrasing; prosody somewhat monotone. Affect mildly constricted but appropriate; mood described as "stressed." Thought process linear and detail-focused; content without delusions or hallucinations. No manic symptoms. Insight fair; she attributes many conflicts to "people assuming things I didn’t mean." Cognition grossly intact. Judgment adequate.

Summary impression: Presentation features a lifelong pattern of social-communication differences across contexts, restricted/repetitive behaviors and insistence on sameness, and sensory sensitivities with functional impairment. Anxiety symptoms are prominent but appear secondary to predictable triggers (social ambiguity, change, sensory overload) rather than generalized, pervasive worry across multiple domains.

demographics: 34-year-old woman, middle school teacher, married, lives with spouse, no children. No tobacco or illicit drug use; drinks alcohol 0–1 drinks/week. No significant medical history; not pregnant. Family history: mother with history of depressive episodes.
clinical_text:
A 34-year-old middle school teacher presents to outpatient psychiatry for worsening mood symptoms over the past 6 weeks, with marked worsening in the last 3–4 weeks. She reports feeling "down and heavy" nearly every day, most of the day. She states, "I wake up already dreading the day, and I can't shake this sadness." She also endorses markedly diminished interest and pleasure: "I used to love planning lessons and going for runs. Now nothing feels worth doing." 

She reports low energy and fatigue daily, describing that routine tasks feel exhausting and she has been calling in sick and leaving work early. She notes impaired concentration and indecisiveness: "I read the same email three times and still can't process it," and says grading papers takes far longer than usual. Sleep is disturbed with early-morning awakening (waking around 4 a.m. and unable to return to sleep) nearly every night. Appetite has decreased with unintentional weight loss of about 8 pounds over the past month. She describes psychomotor slowing noticed by her spouse and colleagues: "People keep asking if I'm okay because I'm moving and talking slower." 

She endorses excessive guilt and feelings of worthlessness: "I feel like I'm failing my students and my husband; I'm a burden." She reports recurrent thoughts of death and passive suicidal ideation over the past 10 days: "Sometimes I think it would be easier if I just didn't wake up," and on two occasions she has briefly thought about "taking a bunch of pills," but denies current intent or a specific plan. She denies any prior suicide attempts. She identifies protective factors including her spouse, close relationship with her sister, and desire not to harm her students or family, and agrees to safety planning and increased monitoring.

Symptoms are causing clinically significant distress and functional impairment, including missed workdays, decreased performance, social withdrawal, and reduced self-care. She denies any history of manic or hypomanic episodes (no periods of abnormally elevated or irritable mood, decreased need for sleep with increased energy, pressured speech, racing thoughts, inflated self-esteem, risky behavior, or markedly increased goal-directed activity). She denies hallucinations or delusional beliefs. She denies panic attacks as the primary issue; anxiety is present but secondary to the pervasive low mood. 

She reports no recent substance use changes and denies stimulant, opioid, or sedative misuse. She is not taking corticosteroids or other medications associated with mood changes. Review of systems is otherwise unremarkable; she reports a recent primary care visit with normal basic labs including thyroid function. There is no evidence that symptoms are better explained by a medical condition. She reports no recent bereavement; the onset followed a period of increasing workplace stress and feelings of being overwhelmed, but symptoms are persistent and pervasive beyond situational triggers.

demographics: 34-year-old woman, married, works full-time as a high school teacher; lives with spouse and two children. No significant medical history. Drinks 1–2 cups of coffee daily, rare alcohol use, denies tobacco or illicit substances.
clinical_text:
A 34-year-old high school teacher presents for evaluation of persistent anxiety and worry that she describes as "constant background noise" for the past 10–11 months. She reports excessive worry occurring most days about multiple areas of life, including her job performance (e.g., lesson observations, grading), her children’s safety and health, finances, and the possibility of making mistakes that could "ruin everything." She states, "Even when nothing is happening, my mind jumps to worst-case scenarios." She finds the worry difficult to control and notes that reassurance provides only brief relief before new worries emerge.

She endorses associated physical and cognitive symptoms occurring on most days: feeling keyed up and restless ("I can’t relax; I’m always bracing for something"), becoming easily fatigued by midday despite adequate effort to rest, difficulty concentrating ("I reread emails three times and still doubt what I wrote"), irritability with family and coworkers ("I snap over small things"), muscle tension in her shoulders and jaw with frequent headaches, and sleep disturbance characterized by difficulty falling asleep due to racing thoughts and waking early to "mentally review" tasks. She reports that these symptoms have gradually intensified over the last year and are not confined to specific situations.

Functionally, she reports significant distress and impairment: she spends excessive time checking school communications, repeatedly reviews household expenses, and frequently seeks reassurance from her spouse. She has begun arriving to work early to "double-check everything," leading to reduced time with family and missed social plans due to feeling overwhelmed. She denies panic attacks, discrete episodes of sudden intense fear, or avoidance specifically related to social scrutiny. She denies obsessions with repetitive compulsions beyond checking driven by worry; her checking is described as an attempt to reduce persistent worry rather than a fixed ritual. She denies trauma-related intrusive memories or hypervigilance tied to a specific event. Mood is described as "stressed and on edge" but she denies persistent depressed mood or loss of interest most days; appetite is stable. She denies manic or hypomanic symptoms. She denies suicidal or homicidal ideation.

She reports no recent medication changes and denies use of stimulants, diet pills, or illicit substances. She has no symptoms suggestive of hyperthyroidism (no heat intolerance, tremor, unexplained weight loss) and no cardiopulmonary complaints other than occasional tension-related chest tightness during worry. Mental status exam: appropriately dressed, cooperative, normal speech, mood "anxious," affect congruent and tense, thought process linear but ruminative, thought content notable for excessive worries across domains, no psychosis, cognition grossly intact though she reports subjective concentration difficulty, insight and judgment fair. She is seeking help because she feels the worry is "taking over" and interfering with her work and home life.

demographics: 29-year-old woman, employed full-time as a project coordinator at a marketing firm; lives with partner; completed college with academic accommodations in later years; no military history; occasional social alcohol use; denies tobacco or illicit substance use.
clinical_text:
CC: "My mind never shuts up, and I keep dropping the ball at work. I’m worried I’m going to get fired."

HPI: The patient is a 29-year-old project coordinator referred for evaluation due to chronic difficulties with attention, organization, and task completion that have become more impairing after a recent promotion requiring independent planning and tracking of multiple deadlines. She reports longstanding patterns of misplacing items ("I lose my keys at least three times a week"), forgetting obligations unless they are immediately entered into her phone, and missing details in emails despite rereading them. She describes frequently starting tasks with strong intention but drifting to another activity within minutes ("I’ll open a spreadsheet, then somehow I’m reorganizing folders, then I’m Googling something random"). She endorses significant procrastination, especially for tasks requiring sustained mental effort (budgets, long reports), and describes "last-minute sprints" to meet deadlines. She notes that even during meetings she must "fight to stay with it," often realizing she has missed parts of the conversation and later asking colleagues to repeat information.

She describes internal restlessness and difficulty remaining seated through longer meetings, frequently fidgeting with pens, tapping her foot, or switching positions. She reports that she often answers before others finish speaking and later regrets sounding "abrupt." She describes interrupting her partner and coworkers when she feels she will "lose the thought" if she does not say it immediately. She denies risky driving, spending sprees, or episodes of elevated mood.

The patient also reports feeling "on edge" and experiencing frequent worry, but when asked to elaborate she links the worry primarily to predictable consequences of disorganization and missed tasks: "I’m not worried about everything—mostly I’m worried I forgot something." She reports the worry spikes after she notices an unread email thread, an approaching deadline, or when she cannot find an important item. She describes repeated checking behaviors (refreshing her inbox, re-reading sent messages, reviewing her calendar) that she experiences as attempts to compensate for forgetfulness rather than rituals driven by intrusive fears. She denies persistent, hard-to-control worry across multiple life domains (finances, health, family safety) on most days; she states, "If my system is working, I’m actually pretty calm." She denies muscle tension most days, denies chronic gastrointestinal symptoms related to worry, and denies panic attacks. Sleep is inconsistent; she reports staying up late "trying to catch up" or becoming distracted by other activities (scrolling, organizing, side projects), rather than being kept awake by pervasive worry.

Course/Onset: She reports similar difficulties since childhood. She recalls being described as "bright but scattered" by teachers and frequently receiving comments such as "does not use time wisely" and "talks in class." She states she often forgot to turn in completed homework and lost worksheets. Her mother, contacted with consent, reports the patient was "always daydreaming," misplaced belongings, and needed repeated reminders for chores. The patient reports that symptoms were present well before age 12. She describes impairment across settings: at work (missed deadlines, errors of omission, difficulty prioritizing), at home (unfinished chores, clutter, forgetting appointments), and in her relationship (partner feels she "isn’t listening" and is frustrated by interruptions and inconsistent follow-through).

Psychiatric history: No prior psychiatric hospitalizations. Brief counseling in college for academic stress. No history of trauma-related nightmares or avoidance symptoms. No history of psychosis. Denies past episodes of markedly decreased need for sleep with increased goal-directed activity or grandiosity. 

Medical history: Unremarkable; no thyroid disease reported. Medications: combined oral contraceptive only. Allergies: none known.

Substance history: Drinks 1–2 alcoholic beverages on weekends. Caffeine: 2–3 coffees daily, sometimes more when behind. Denies cannabis, stimulants, or other illicit drugs.

Family history: Father described as "disorganized" and chronically late; no formal diagnoses. Maternal aunt with history of depression.

Mental status exam (abbrev.): Well-groomed, cooperative. Speech normal rate/volume; occasionally tangential but redirectable. Mood "stressed"; affect mildly anxious but reactive. Thought process linear overall with moments of circumstantiality. No suicidal or homicidal ideation. No delusions or hallucinations. Cognition: alert and oriented; working memory appears strained during serial tasks; attention variable. Insight and judgment fair.

Clinical impression: Lifelong and pervasive pattern of inattention (difficulty sustaining attention, disorganization, procrastination, losing items, forgetfulness, failure to follow through) with associated restlessness and impulsive conversational style, causing functional impairment in occupational and interpersonal domains. Reported worry appears largely secondary to repeated lapses and performance consequences, fluctuates with external demands, and is not described as excessive, pervasive, or uncontrollable across multiple domains.

demographics: 32-year-old woman, paramedic (EMS), divorced, lives alone, no children, some college, currently on modified duty after a workplace incident.
clinical_text:
Ms. R is a 32-year-old paramedic referred by occupational health for persistent sleep disturbance, irritability, and anxiety that began after a call 5 months ago. She reports responding to a multi-vehicle collision in which a driver was trapped and severely injured. She describes being unable to free the driver before the vehicle caught fire and states, "I can still hear him yelling and the smell of smoke hits me out of nowhere." She reports that during the event she felt "frozen" and afterward had a sense of unreality and "watching myself from outside." She denies prior similar symptoms before this incident.

Since the call, she endorses recurrent, involuntary distressing memories that occur daily, often triggered by sirens, the smell of gasoline, or seeing wrecked cars. She reports nightmares 3–4 nights per week with themes of being trapped or unable to help someone; she wakes sweating and disoriented and sometimes checks her apartment for smoke. She describes episodes in which she briefly feels "back there on scene," lasting seconds to a minute, during which she loses awareness of her surroundings and then "snaps out of it" with strong fear. She avoids driving on highways and refuses to ride in the front passenger seat. She has called out sick to avoid shift work that involves motor vehicle collisions and states, "If dispatch says crash, my stomach drops and I try to trade calls." She also avoids news, videos, or conversations about traffic fatalities and becomes visibly tense when coworkers discuss similar calls.

She reports persistent negative mood and cognitions: guilt and self-blame ("I should have done more; I failed him"), diminished interest in hobbies (she stopped running and meeting friends), and feeling detached ("I’m there but not really there"). She describes emotional numbing and difficulty experiencing positive emotions, stating, "Even when something good happens, it doesn’t land." She endorses persistent fear and anger, with increased irritability and verbal outbursts at work and at home. She reports hypervigilance (constantly scanning intersections and exits), exaggerated startle response to loud bangs or sirens, and difficulty concentrating ("I read the same paragraph over and over"). Sleep is fragmented with prolonged sleep onset and frequent awakenings.

Functionally, she has requested modified duty due to symptoms and has received a written warning for snapping at a supervisor and making documentation errors. Socially, she has withdrawn from friends and rarely leaves home except for errands. She reports occasional panic-like surges when exposed to triggers (heart racing, shortness of breath, trembling), typically lasting 10–15 minutes, and fears they will happen while driving. She has begun drinking 2–3 beers most nights to "shut my brain off"; she denies morning drinking, blackouts, or withdrawal symptoms but acknowledges increased tolerance. She denies current suicidal intent or plan; she endorses passive thoughts such as "I wish I could just not wake up" after nightmares, without intent, and cites fear of hurting family and career goals as protective factors.

Past psychiatric history is notable for brief counseling in college for situational stress; no history of manic episodes, psychosis, or prior trauma-related symptoms. She denies head injury, seizures, or other medical contributors. She is not taking psychiatric medications. Mental status exam: cooperative, tearful at times; mood "on edge"; affect constricted and anxious; thought process linear; thought content notable for guilt and intrusive memories; no hallucinations or delusions; cognition grossly intact; insight and judgment fair. Symptoms have persisted for more than one month and cause clinically significant distress and impairment. She reports the symptoms are not solely attributable to alcohol use and predated the increase in drinking.

demographics: 22-year-old man, third-year computer science student, lives with roommates near campus; part-time library shelving job; no substance use; no significant medical history.
clinical_text:
Reason for visit: Referred by university counseling after repeated complaints from peers and a professor that he seems “rude,” “uninterested,” and “hard to talk to,” and after he became highly distressed when a group-project schedule changed.

History of presenting concerns: The patient reports long-standing difficulty understanding social expectations and maintaining reciprocal conversations. He states, “I don’t know when I’m supposed to talk. People say I’m talking at them, not with them.” During the interview he gives lengthy, detail-heavy answers focused on his preferred topics, with limited awareness of the clinician’s cues to shift topics. He rarely asks questions back and often interprets questions literally (e.g., when asked how his mood has been, he replies with an exact description of his sleep schedule and caffeine intake rather than describing emotions). He reports being confused by sarcasm and indirect requests: “If someone says, ‘It’s cold in here,’ I don’t know if they want me to close the window or if they’re just stating a fact.”

Social communication/interaction: He describes persistent difficulty making and keeping friends despite wanting social connection: “I want friends, but I don’t know the steps.” He prefers structured interactions around shared activities and struggles with unstructured socializing. He reports frequently missing nonverbal cues and being told his facial expression looks “blank” or “serious” even when he feels neutral. In session, eye contact is fleeting and not well integrated with speech; his gestures are minimal and somewhat stiff. He describes difficulty gauging others’ interest: “I can’t tell if they’re bored until they leave.” He also reports past misunderstandings in dating attempts, saying he could not tell when someone was flirting versus being polite. He tends to stand too close without realizing and has been asked to “give space.”

Restricted/repetitive behaviors and interests: He reports a strong need for routines and becomes distressed by unexpected changes. He describes becoming “panicky and stuck” when a class was moved to a different building, and he needed to walk the route repeatedly the night before to feel calm. He keeps a highly rigid daily schedule and eats the same lunch most days, stating, “If it’s different, it feels wrong and I can’t focus.” He exhibits repetitive motor behaviors when anxious, including hand-flapping and rocking while seated; he acknowledges this and says, “I do it to settle my nerves.” He also describes repetitive speech patterns, including rehearsing specific scripts before phone calls and repeating phrases under his breath after conversations.

He has an intense, circumscribed interest in public transit systems and route optimization, present since childhood. He spends several hours daily mapping bus routes and tracking timetables, and he can recite route numbers and transfer times in great detail. He reports that this topic “makes sense and is calming,” and that he often brings it up in conversation even when others are discussing unrelated matters. Roommates complain that he “monologues” about it and becomes irritated if interrupted.

Sensory features: He describes strong sensory sensitivities, including discomfort with fluorescent lights (“It’s like a buzzing in my head”), certain fabric textures, and loud mixed-noise environments such as cafeterias (“I can’t separate the sounds; it feels painful”). He wears noise-canceling headphones daily and avoids crowded dining halls, choosing to eat alone in a quiet area.

Developmental history: Symptoms were present early. His mother (contacted with consent) reports he spoke his first words on time but had an unusual communication style, “talked like a little professor,” and often lectured about his interests. She reports limited pretend play, a preference for lining up toy cars by size/color, and distress when routines changed. As a child he preferred solitary activities, had difficulty with playdates, and was frequently described by teachers as “very bright but socially unaware.” He received social-skills support in elementary school due to peer relationship difficulties and frequent misunderstandings of classroom social rules.

Current functioning and impairment: Academically he performs well in technical coursework but struggles in group projects, presentations requiring audience awareness, and networking. At work, he is reliable with tasks but has been coached about tone of voice and responding to patrons’ small talk. He reports significant exhaustion after social interactions and increased anxiety when routines are disrupted. He denies current or past hallucinations, delusions, manic episodes, or panic attacks unrelated to change/sensory overload. Mood is generally “okay,” though he reports frustration and loneliness related to social difficulties. No history of self-harm. He denies suicidal or homicidal ideation.

Mental status examination (salient features): Appearance neat, behavior cooperative. Speech is fluent, sometimes overly formal, with occasional pedantic phrasing; prosody somewhat monotone. Affect constricted but appropriate to content. Thought process linear but overly detailed; content focused on schedules and transit details when given the opportunity. Insight into having social difficulties is partial; judgment intact for safety.

Differential considerations: Intellectual functioning appears average to above average based on academic history and vocabulary; there is no evidence that the social-communication deficits are better explained by global developmental delay. The pattern is longstanding, present since early childhood, pervasive across settings, and causes clinically significant functional impairment in social and occupational domains.

demographics: 34-year-old woman, emergency department nurse, lives with partner, no children; college educated; no military history.
clinical_text:
34-year-old ED nurse presents for evaluation due to 8 weeks of worsening mood and functioning. She reports feeling “down and empty almost all day, every day,” with markedly decreased interest in previously enjoyed activities (stopped running, declined social invitations, “I just don’t care about anything”). She describes prominent fatigue (“I feel like I’m moving through wet cement”), reduced concentration at work (double-checking charts repeatedly, forgetting routine tasks), and increased tearfulness. Sleep is disrupted with early-morning awakening (waking at 3–4 AM and unable to return to sleep) and occasional difficulty falling asleep due to ruminative thoughts about “messing everything up.” Appetite is reduced with an unintentional 8 lb weight loss over the past month. She endorses feelings of worthlessness and excessive guilt disproportionate to events (“I’m a bad nurse… I ruin everything”), and she has become increasingly indecisive.

She reports passive thoughts of death several times per week (“Sometimes I think it would be easier not to wake up”), and in the last week she had fleeting thoughts of “taking a bunch of pills,” but denies preparing, acquiring medications for that purpose, writing notes, or making plans. She denies intent, citing her partner and family as reasons for living. She agrees to a safety plan and means restriction. No history of suicide attempts or self-injury.

History includes a distressing work incident about 5 months ago: a young patient died during a resuscitation despite prolonged efforts. Around the same period, she witnessed a separate event in the ED where an intoxicated visitor became aggressive and punched a staff member. She describes these as “awful” and says she felt shaken afterward. Because of this history, she worried she might be “traumatized.” She endorses increased startle when hearing sudden loud noises in the hospital and some avoidance of watching medical dramas at home because they feel “too heavy” right now. However, she denies recurrent, intrusive, involuntary memories of either incident; denies flashbacks, dissociative episodes, or feeling as though the events are happening again. She denies persistent physiological reactivity or panic specifically triggered by reminders; instead, she describes a more constant low mood and pervasive negative self-appraisal. She has had a few unpleasant dreams in the past month, but they are nonspecific (themes of being late or failing at work) rather than reenactments of either event. She continues to work in the same ED, does not avoid the trauma-related location, and does not avoid discussions of the incidents during supervision; she states, “It’s not like I can’t talk about it—I just feel hopeless all the time.” She denies persistent hypervigilance outside of work, denies irritability or angry outbursts, and denies reckless/self-destructive behaviors.

No history of manic or hypomanic episodes: she denies periods of elevated/expansive mood, decreased need for sleep with increased energy, pressured speech, inflated self-esteem, racing thoughts, or risky spending/sexual behavior. She denies hallucinations, delusions, or paranoia. Anxiety symptoms are present but appear secondary to rumination and functional impairment; she does not report discrete panic attacks.

Past psychiatric history: no prior formal treatment; reports one brief period of low mood in college after a breakup that resolved within 2 weeks without impairment. Medical history: mild asthma; no thyroid disease. Medications: albuterol PRN; no steroids recently. Substances: drinks 1–2 glasses of wine on weekends; denies binge drinking; denies cannabis or other substances. Family history: mother with recurrent depressive episodes. Social history: supportive partner; increasing social withdrawal over last 2 months; work performance has declined and she has used three sick days in the past month.

Mental status exam: well-groomed, slowed movements, soft speech. Mood “numb and sad,” affect constricted and tearful at times. Thought process linear but ruminative. Thought content notable for worthlessness and guilt; passive death wishes without intent; no psychosis. Cognition grossly intact; attention subjectively impaired. Insight and judgment fair. Overall presentation suggests a sustained depressive syndrome with significant occupational and social impairment; trauma exposure is present in the history, but the symptom pattern is not characterized by persistent intrusive re-experiencing, trauma-linked avoidance, or dissociative phenomena.

demographics: 34-year-old woman, married, works as a project coordinator at a mid-sized construction firm; lives with spouse and 2-year-old child; no current substance use; drinks 1–2 coffees daily.
clinical_text:
A 34-year-old married project coordinator presents for evaluation due to persistent anxiety and physical tension. She reports that for the past 10–12 months she has felt "on edge most days," with worry that feels "constant and exhausting." The worry occurs more days than not and spans multiple areas: fear of making mistakes at work (e.g., missing an email, misreading a schedule), finances ("What if we can’t cover daycare if something happens?"), the health and safety of her child (e.g., mentally replaying possibilities of accidents or illness), and concerns about her spouse’s job stability. She describes the worry as difficult to control: "Even when I tell myself it’s not rational, it keeps running like a playlist." She spends significant time seeking reassurance (checking messages repeatedly, rereading sent emails, reviewing calendars multiple times) and has trouble disengaging from "what if" thoughts at night.

She endorses several associated symptoms: (1) restlessness/feeling keyed up—"I can’t relax; even on the couch my leg is bouncing"; (2) easy fatigue—she feels drained by mid-afternoon despite adequate opportunities to rest; (3) difficulty concentrating—"I read the same paragraph three times" and at work she loses her train of thought during meetings; (4) irritability—snappier with her spouse and child, followed by guilt; (5) muscle tension—chronic tightness in her neck/jaw with occasional tension headaches; and (6) sleep disturbance—difficulty falling asleep due to worry and intermittent early-morning awakening. She reports the symptoms have caused clinically significant distress and impairment: reduced productivity at work, avoidance of taking on new tasks, strained family interactions, and diminished enjoyment of leisure activities. She denies that these symptoms are limited to performance situations or social scrutiny; she worries even when alone and on weekends.

Non-standard features include prominent gastrointestinal symptoms that fluctuate with stress (episodic abdominal cramping and loose stools), for which her primary care clinician previously suggested a functional bowel pattern; she notes, "If I have a stressful meeting, my stomach goes crazy." She also describes occasional brief surges of anxiety with palpitations and shortness of breath (lasting 5–10 minutes) when she is already worrying, but these episodes are not unexpected out of the blue and do not lead to persistent fear of future attacks; rather, they are experienced as peaks of her ongoing tension.

She denies depressed mood most of the day nearly every day, anhedonia, or suicidal ideation, though she feels "worn out" and self-critical. She denies obsessions with ritualized compulsions, traumatic re-experiencing, discrete phobic triggers, or episodes of abnormally elevated mood, decreased need for sleep, or increased goal-directed activity. She reports no history of psychosis. She denies current or past problematic alcohol or drug use and is not using stimulants or weight-loss agents; she drinks one cup of coffee in the morning and occasionally a second at lunch.

Medical history is notable only for episodic tension headaches and the stress-related gastrointestinal complaints; she has no known thyroid disease and no recent significant weight change. Current medications: none. She has not previously received psychiatric treatment. Family history is positive for a mother described as a "worrier" who was treated with medication for anxiety. Mental status examination: well-groomed, cooperative; speech normal rate/volume; mood "anxious," affect tense but reactive; thought process linear with frequent anticipatory worry content; no delusions or hallucinations; cognition grossly intact though she reports subjective distractibility; insight and judgment fair. She is seeking help because she feels her worry is "taking over" and wants strategies and/or medication to regain control and improve sleep and functioning.

demographics: 28-year-old woman, works as a project coordinator at a mid-sized software company; lives with partner; college graduate; no children.
clinical_text:
Chief concern: “My brain feels like a browser with 30 tabs open. I’m always behind, even when I’m trying hard.”

History of present illness: The patient presents for evaluation of longstanding difficulties with attention regulation and organization that have become more impairing after a recent promotion requiring independent planning, frequent context-switching, and documentation. She reports persistent problems sustaining focus during meetings and while writing status updates: “I read the same paragraph five times and still don’t know what it says.” She often starts tasks with good intentions but drifts to other activities (checking messages, reorganizing a spreadsheet, researching unrelated topics) and later realizes she did not complete the original assignment. She describes frequent careless mistakes in routine work (wrong dates on calendar invites, missing attachments, overlooking small instructions), and she tends to miss details unless she is under significant time pressure.

She reports that she “misplaces everything” (badge, earbuds, keys) and keeps multiple sets of items to cope. She describes chronic difficulty organizing multi-step tasks, estimating time, and prioritizing: “If there are five tasks, they all feel equally urgent, and I freeze.” She often procrastinates on sustained mental effort tasks such as expense reports, long emails, and preparing project documentation, describing them as “physically painful to start.” She frequently forgets obligations unless they are immediately entered into reminders, including paying bills and responding to messages. Her partner corroborates that she leaves tasks half-finished at home (laundry started but not moved to the dryer, cooking begun then abandoned) and can appear not to listen when spoken to directly, especially if she is on her phone or thinking about something else.

Hyperactivity/impulsivity features are present but less prominent. She describes an internal sense of restlessness (“I’m buzzing inside”) and fidgeting (foot tapping, picking at cuticles) during meetings. She gets up frequently to refill water or “walk a lap” in the office. She talks rapidly when excited and sometimes interrupts: “I blurt it out because if I wait, I’ll forget.” She denies impulsive spending sprees, reckless driving, or recurrent physical fights.

Course and developmental history: Symptoms are described as chronic and trace back to childhood. She recalls teacher comments in elementary school such as “bright but daydreams” and “missing homework even when she knows the material.” She reports needing parental prompting to start and complete chores and school projects, frequently losing school supplies, and routinely doing assignments the night before they were due. She states the difficulties were present across settings (home and school) and continued through high school and college, where she relied on coping strategies including last-minute “all-nighters,” heavy use of color-coded planners, and choosing classes based on perceived workload. Despite strong test performance, she struggled with sustained reading, lengthy writing assignments, and managing deadlines.

Current impairment: At work, she reports being placed on a performance improvement plan focused on documentation quality, follow-through, and missed deadlines. She spends extra hours “making up” work after others leave, which has contributed to fatigue and conflict with her partner. At home, she reports household disorganization and frequent arguments about unfinished tasks and forgetfulness. She reports reduced self-esteem and guilt: “I feel lazy, but I’m not trying to be.”

Associated symptoms and comorbidity considerations: She reports mild generalized worry about making mistakes at work and occasional difficulty falling asleep due to “replaying the day,” occurring several nights per week. She denies panic attacks. She denies persistent low mood most days, anhedonia, suicidal ideation, or history of self-harm. She denies episodes of abnormally elevated mood, decreased need for sleep with increased goal-directed activity, grandiosity, or other manic symptoms. She denies psychotic symptoms. She reports occasional use of cannabis (edible) 1–2 times per month “to unwind,” and drinks alcohol socially (1–3 drinks/week); she denies other substance use. Caffeine intake is 2–3 coffees daily. Sleep averages 6–7 hours on weekdays, longer on weekends.

Medical history: No known thyroid disease, seizure history, or head injury with loss of consciousness. No current medications. No known medication allergies.

Family and psychosocial history: She reports a brother who “always had trouble sitting still and barely got through school,” never formally evaluated; mother described as chronically disorganized. She is in a stable relationship but notes increasing tension related to follow-through and forgetfulness. She enjoys exercise and hobbies but often abandons new projects after initial enthusiasm.

Mental status exam (summary): Well-groomed, cooperative. Speech normal volume, occasionally rapid when describing work issues. Mood “stressed”; affect congruent. Thought process generally linear but tangential when recounting recent events; easily redirected. No delusions or hallucinations. Cognition grossly intact; attention fluctuates during interview (asks for questions to be repeated once). Insight and judgment fair.

Clinical impression: Presentation is consistent with a chronic pattern of inattention with some restlessness, with onset in childhood, presence across settings, and clinically significant impairment. Mild generalized anxiety and sleep-onset insomnia appear secondary to ongoing functional stress and are not sufficient to account for the longstanding attentional and organizational difficulties. No evidence for a primary mood or psychotic disorder at this time.

demographics: 32-year-old woman, married, one child (age 6), employed as a paramedic; no prior psychiatric hospitalizations; medical history notable for migraine headaches; drinks alcohol 3–4 nights/week (2–3 drinks) since the incident.
clinical_text:
Ms. R is a 32-year-old paramedic referred by her primary care clinician for persistent anxiety, insomnia, and worsening irritability. She reports that 11 months ago she was the first responder to a multicar crash involving fatalities, including a child who died despite resuscitation attempts. She recalls seeing the child’s face and hearing the parent screaming. She states, “I can still smell the gasoline and blood like it’s happening again.”

Since the incident, she experiences intrusive, unwanted memories several times per day, often triggered by sirens, the smell of fuel, or seeing children in car seats. She reports recurrent distressing dreams 2–3 times per week in which she is “back on the road” and wakes “soaked in sweat” with her heart racing. On two occasions while driving past the crash site, she felt as if the scene was replaying in real time and briefly lost awareness of her surroundings; she describes, “It was like I was watching myself from outside my body,” followed by intense panic and a need to pull over.

She actively avoids reminders: she has changed routes to avoid the highway, refuses to watch news stories about accidents, and has asked her supervisor to keep her off pediatric calls. She notes emotional and cognitive changes since the event, including persistent guilt (“I should have done more, I failed that kid”), shame, and a shift in beliefs (“The world is dangerous; something terrible can happen any second”). She reports diminished interest in socializing with coworkers, feels detached from her spouse (“I’m there but not really there”), and describes a restricted range of positive emotion: “Even when my daughter is laughing, I can’t feel it the way I used to.”

Arousal symptoms are prominent. She endorses chronic hypervigilance, sitting with her back to the wall in restaurants and scanning exits. She has an exaggerated startle response to sudden noises and becomes irritable with low frustration tolerance; her spouse reports she “snaps” over minor issues. She has difficulty concentrating at work and at home, often rereading documentation multiple times. Sleep is fragmented with prolonged sleep onset and frequent awakenings; she sleeps 3–5 hours/night and reports daytime fatigue.

Symptoms began within weeks after the crash, have persisted for >10 months, and cause clinically significant impairment: she has called out of work multiple times, performance reviews note reduced focus, and her marital relationship is strained. She denies a history of similar symptoms prior to the incident. She denies current or past manic episodes. She reports intermittent passive thoughts such as “I wish I could just not wake up,” particularly after nightmares, but denies active suicidal intent, plan, or preparatory behaviors; protective factors include her daughter and engagement with treatment.

Regarding substances, she reports increased alcohol use since the incident to “shut my brain off,” though she denies morning drinking, withdrawal symptoms, or legal consequences. She denies illicit drug use. She is not taking steroids or stimulants. Neurologic review is negative for seizures or head injury. She reports occasional brief episodes of palpitations and chest tightness when confronted with reminders; these are situational and followed by avoidance. Mental status exam: alert and oriented; affect anxious and constricted; mood “on edge”; thought process linear; thought content notable for guilt and threat-based beliefs; no hallucinations or fixed delusions; insight and judgment fair. She becomes visibly tense when recounting the crash and pauses to “catch my breath.”

demographics: 28-year-old nonbinary person (they/them), lives alone, works as a software quality assurance analyst in a mid-sized tech company; completed a bachelor’s degree in computer science; no legal history; limited social network outside of one long-term friend online.
clinical_text:
They present to an outpatient psychiatry clinic at the suggestion of their primary care clinician due to chronic social difficulties, escalating workplace stress, and episodes of shutdown-like withdrawal after changes in routine. They report, “I can do my job, but the social part feels like acting all day. When I get home, I’m wiped out and I can’t talk to anyone.” They deny current suicidal intent but endorse intermittent passive thoughts during periods of overwhelm (“I wish I could disappear for a day”) without plan or prior attempts.

History indicates longstanding differences in social communication. In childhood, caregivers described them as “bright but in their own world.” They reportedly spoke early with an unusually formal tone and tended to monologue about preferred topics. They had difficulty with back-and-forth conversation, often missing cues that others were bored or wanting to change the subject. They recall being confused by implied meanings and sarcasm: “If someone says ‘It’s fine,’ I assume it’s fine unless they literally tell me otherwise.” In sessions, their speech is fluent and detailed but can become overly precise; they sometimes answer questions with extensive contextual information and need gentle redirection. They report needing to rehearse conversations and keep a mental script, especially for phone calls: “I write down what I’ll say. If the other person goes off-script, my brain stalls.”

They describe persistent difficulty developing and maintaining relationships. They have a strong desire for connection but find most socializing exhausting and unpredictable. They report having been bullied in middle school for being “weird” and “too intense.” They have had one brief romantic relationship that ended due to communication misunderstandings; they describe not noticing the partner’s growing dissatisfaction until it was explicitly stated. They prefer solitary activities, maintain an online friendship centered around shared interests, and rarely attend group events. They state, “I don’t know what people want from small talk. It feels pointless, but I know it’s expected.”

Nonverbal communication differences are noted and reported. During the interview, eye contact is intermittent and appears effortful; they look away when thinking and report eye contact can feel “like staring into a light.” Their facial expression is somewhat limited in range, and prosody is occasionally monotone. They describe difficulty interpreting others’ facial expressions unless they are overt: “I can tell if someone is angry, but subtle stuff—no.” They report being told they come across as blunt or disinterested even when they are engaged.

Restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are prominent. They describe deep, circumscribed interests since early childhood (e.g., transit maps, then computer hardware, currently niche data-logging tools and a specific strategy game). They can spend hours researching and organizing information and experience distress if interrupted: “If I’m in the middle of a system, stopping feels physically uncomfortable.” They keep extensive lists and spreadsheets for daily tasks and food intake and feel calmer when information is categorized.

They endorse a strong preference for sameness and routine. A recent office reorganization (new seating plan, different daily stand-up format, and increased open-office noise) triggered marked anxiety, reduced appetite, and two episodes where they became unable to speak for several hours after work. They describe these episodes as “my brain goes offline; I can’t find words, and I just lie in the dark.” They also report distress when plans change at the last minute and rely on predictable meal choices and commute routes.

Sensory differences are significant. They are highly sensitive to certain sounds (keyboard clacking, fluorescent light buzz), particular clothing textures, and strong smells. They wear noise-canceling headphones most of the day and avoid crowded grocery stores. They describe “sensory overload” leading to irritability and shutdown. They also seek sensory comfort through repetitive movements; during the interview, they intermittently rub their fingertips together and rock subtly when discussing stressful topics, which they report helps them self-regulate: “It stops the static feeling.”

Functionally, they are technically strong at work and receive positive feedback on accuracy, but interpersonal demands are impairing. They struggle with ambiguous instructions, office politics, and group brainstorming. They report miscommunications with coworkers, difficulty knowing when to join conversations, and anxiety about being perceived as rude. They have requested remote work as an accommodation due to noise and interruptions.

Comorbid symptoms include chronic generalized worry, muscle tension, and sleep-onset insomnia that worsened with workplace changes. They report frequent rumination (“I replay conversations for hours to figure out what I did wrong”) and occasional panic-like surges in overstimulating environments, though they do not avoid leaving home entirely. They also endorse lifelong attentional variability: strong focus on preferred tasks but difficulty initiating boring tasks, losing track of time, and forgetting non-preferred chores; however, their academic record was strong with structured deadlines. Mood symptoms include episodic low mood and fatigue during periods of prolonged social masking and sensory stress, but they deny sustained anhedonia or pervasive hopelessness outside of these contexts.

Developmental history (per patient report and a brief collateral call with a parent) supports early onset. As a toddler/young child, they preferred lining up objects, became upset if items were moved, and showed intense interest in specific topics. They had few peer friendships, often played alone, and were described as “literal” and “rule-bound.” No history suggests global developmental delay or intellectual disability; they met academic milestones and have above-average verbal and analytical abilities. There is no history of psychosis, mania, or substance use disorder. Medical history is notable only for migraines; they take no psychotropic medications currently.

Mental status examination: appearance neat and casual; behavior cooperative but somewhat guarded initially; psychomotor mildly restless with subtle rocking; speech normal rate, occasionally overly detailed; mood “stressed”; affect constricted but congruent; thought process logical and goal-directed; thought content notable for worry and social self-criticism; no delusions or hallucinations; cognition grossly intact; insight fair; judgment intact. Overall presentation reflects a longstanding pattern of social-communication differences and restricted/repetitive behaviors with sensory sensitivities, present since early development and causing clinically significant impairment, particularly in social and occupational functioning, with concurrent anxiety and stress-related shutdown episodes.

demographics: 34-year-old woman, married, works full-time as a pediatric nurse on rotating shifts; lives with spouse and one child. No current substance use; drinks 1–2 coffees daily, rare alcohol. No significant medical history; recent primary care labs reportedly normal (CBC, TSH per patient).
clinical_text:
She presents for evaluation due to a 7-week period of worsening mood and functioning. She reports feeling “down and numb most days,” with marked loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities (stopped running and declined social invitations, “I just don’t care anymore”). She describes persistent fatigue and low energy (“everything feels heavy”), and notes reduced productivity at work with increased errors in charting. She endorses impaired concentration (“I read the same paragraph three times and nothing sticks”) and indecisiveness.

Sleep has changed: she falls asleep but wakes at 3–4 a.m. most nights and cannot return to sleep, leading to daytime exhaustion. Appetite is decreased with an unintentional 8-pound weight loss over the last month. She reports psychomotor slowing observed by her spouse (“she moves like she’s wading through mud”), and she herself says she has been speaking less at home.

She describes prominent self-critical thoughts and feelings of worthlessness: “I’m a burden. My family would be better off if I wasn’t dragging everyone down.” She reports guilt that feels excessive and disproportionate (“I can’t stop replaying every small mistake at work like it proves I’m incompetent”). She acknowledges intermittent passive thoughts of death over the past two weeks (“sometimes I think it would be easier not to wake up”), but denies a plan, intent, rehearsal behaviors, or access to firearms. Protective factors include her child and spouse; she states, “I don’t want to do anything to myself—I just want the pain to stop.”

Anxiety symptoms are present but appear temporally linked to the mood decline. Over the last 1–2 months, she has been more keyed up and tense at work, worrying about making a harmful mistake and being judged by colleagues. She notes muscle tension in her shoulders and occasional stomach “knots” before shifts. However, she does not describe a long-standing pattern of worry across multiple life areas, and she reports the worry is largely confined to work performance and is not present on days off. She can sometimes redirect her worry with reassurance or task checklists and does not describe it as uncontrollable. She denies frequent panic attacks, compulsions, traumatic re-experiencing, or avoidance behaviors beyond reduced social engagement related to low motivation.

She denies any history of periods of abnormally elevated mood, decreased need for sleep with increased energy, grandiosity, pressured speech, risky behaviors, or marked increases in goal-directed activity. She denies hallucinations or delusional beliefs. She has no current grief trigger; stressors include recent staffing shortages and rotating shifts. No recent medication changes. She denies stimulant, cannabis, or illicit substance use.

Functional impact is significant: increased absenteeism, withdrawing from friends, decreased parenting engagement (“I’m physically there but emotionally absent”), and reduced self-care. She is seeking help because “this isn’t me, and it’s not getting better.”

demographics: 34-year-old woman, married, works as a project coordinator at a mid-sized tech company; lives with spouse and one preschool-aged child. No military history. Drinks 1–2 cups of coffee daily; rare alcohol use; denies tobacco or illicit substances.
clinical_text:
Ms. L is a 34-year-old project coordinator who presents for evaluation due to “constant worrying that I can’t shut off,” worsening over the past year. She reports feeling anxious and keyed up on most days for at least 8–10 months, with worries spanning multiple areas: work performance (“I’m sure I’ll miss something and get fired”), finances (“What if we can’t cover an emergency?”), her child’s safety/health (“If he coughs I spiral into thinking it’s something serious”), and her own health (“I keep thinking something’s wrong with me even when tests are fine”). She notes that the worries feel excessive relative to the situation and that reassurance provides only brief relief. She describes difficulty controlling the worry: “I tell myself to stop, but it keeps running like a radio in the background.”

She endorses associated physical and cognitive symptoms occurring on most days: restlessness (“I’m on edge, like I can’t fully relax”), easy fatigability (“By late afternoon I’m wiped out but still tense”), difficulty concentrating (“I read the same email three times and still feel unsure”), irritability (“Little things set me off, then I feel guilty”), muscle tension (tight shoulders/jaw with frequent tension headaches), and sleep disturbance (takes 60–90 minutes to fall asleep due to rumination; wakes at 3–4 a.m. thinking about tasks; averages ~5–6 hours/night). She reports functional impact: she spends significant time checking calendars, rereading messages, and seeking reassurance from her spouse; she avoids delegating at work and stays late to “make sure nothing goes wrong,” leading to burnout and increased conflict at home.

Non-standard features include intermittent gastrointestinal distress during periods of heightened stress (abdominal cramping and loose stools before meetings), which her primary care clinician previously characterized as stress-related; she also reports occasional brief surges of intense anxiety with palpitations and shortness of breath when she receives unexpected work calls, typically lasting 5–10 minutes, but she does not fear having another attack or change behavior specifically to avoid future episodes. She denies persistent avoidance of public places, and she continues to attend work and errands.

Mood symptoms are present but do not dominate the clinical picture. She describes feeling “drained and discouraged” at times and less enjoyment in hobbies due to preoccupation with worry, but she denies sustained low mood most of the day nearly every day for weeks at a time. Appetite is largely unchanged. She denies suicidal ideation, intent, or past attempts. There is no history suggestive of manic or hypomanic episodes (no periods of decreased need for sleep with increased energy, grandiosity, or risky behavior).

She denies obsessions with ritualized compulsions (no repetitive checking driven by intrusive taboo thoughts; her checking is described as attempts to reduce generalized doubt and prevent mistakes), denies trauma-related re-experiencing or hypervigilance tied to a specific traumatic event, and denies social fear focused on scrutiny or humiliation as the primary driver (she worries broadly, including when alone). She does not report hallucinations or delusional beliefs.

Medical history is notable for episodic tension headaches and the above GI complaints; no known thyroid disease. Current medications: occasional ibuprofen. She denies stimulant use and reports stable caffeine intake. Recent basic labs through her primary care clinician (including thyroid screening) were reportedly normal. Family history includes a mother described as a “chronic worrier” and a father with alcohol use problems in remission. Psychosocial stressors include increased workload after a team reorganization and childcare disruptions.

Mental status exam: well-groomed, cooperative, mildly fidgety. Speech normal rate and tone. Mood “anxious,” affect tense but reactive. Thought process linear; thought content notable for excessive worry and catastrophizing; no suicidal or homicidal ideation. Cognition grossly intact, though attention is mildly impaired by anxiety. Insight and judgment fair. She is motivated for treatment, stating, “I don’t want to live in my head like this.”

demographics: 29-year-old woman, employed as a UX designer at a mid-sized tech company; lives with a roommate; completed a bachelor’s degree with extended deadlines; no significant medical history; occasional alcohol use, denies illicit substances.
clinical_text:
Chief concern: “My brain is like a browser with 40 tabs open—some are playing music and I can’t find which one.”

History of present illness: The patient presents for evaluation of longstanding problems with focus, organization, and follow-through that have become more impairing after a recent promotion requiring more independent project management.
