She reports nightmares 2–3 nights per week in which she re-lives the incident. On two occasions she describes brief episodes while driving past the venue where she felt as if she was "back there" and had to pull over due to intense fear, sweating, and shaking. She becomes visibly distressed when discussing the event and reports marked physiologic reactivity (heart racing, nausea) when she hears news reports about shootings.

She avoids reminders: she refuses assignments in the neighborhood where the incident occurred, avoids the venue entirely, and will not watch news coverage related to violence. She states, "If I start thinking about it, I can’t shut it off, so I just don’t go there," and she quickly changes the subject when coworkers bring up the event. She has stopped attending large gatherings and no longer goes to the gym during busy hours because "I need to know where every exit is." She reports persistent negative beliefs since the incident: "The world is unsafe," and "If I relax, something bad will happen." She endorses intense self-blame about her coworker’s death—"I should have done more, I keep replaying what I missed"—despite acknowledging she followed protocol. She describes chronic feelings of fear, guilt, and anger, with reduced capacity to experience positive emotions: "Even when something good happens, it doesn’t land." She feels detached from her partner and friends, saying she is "watching life from behind glass" and has become socially withdrawn.

Over the past 7–8 weeks, her symptoms have worsened with pervasive low mood most of the day nearly every day. She reports marked loss of interest in previously enjoyable activities (running, cooking, and spending time with friends). She notes decreased appetite with unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over two months. Sleep is fragmented; she has difficulty falling asleep due to scanning the apartment and repeatedly checking door locks, and she wakes early after nightmares, then cannot return to sleep. She reports persistent fatigue and low energy, stating, "I’m exhausted all the time, like I’m moving through mud." Concentration has declined—she rereads the same charting repeatedly and makes minor documentation errors at work, which is new for her. She describes feelings of worthlessness and excessive guilt that extend beyond the traumatic event: "I’m failing at everything—work, my relationship, being a decent person." Her partner reports she has become more irritable and "snaps" over small issues; the patient acknowledges increased anger and impatience and says she is "on edge" and easily startled by sudden noises.

She endorses passive thoughts of death occurring several times in the last month: "Sometimes I think it would be easier if I just didn’t wake up." She denies a specific plan or intent and denies preparatory behaviors. She identifies protective factors including her partner, responsibility to her EMS team, and not wanting her family to experience loss. She agrees to seek help and to use crisis resources if suicidal thoughts intensify.

Functionally, she has used increased sick days, has requested fewer high-acuity calls, and has received feedback about decreased focus. At home, she avoids intimacy, spends more time alone, and has stopped responding to friends’ messages. She denies hallucinations, delusions, or panic attacks unrelated to trauma cues. She denies periods of abnormally elevated mood, decreased need for sleep with increased energy, grandiosity, pressured speech, or risky spending. She denies recent substance escalation. Basic labs obtained by primary care (CBC, CMP, TSH) were reportedly normal, and there is no evidence that symptoms are attributable to a medical condition or substances.

Mental status exam: Appears stated age, mildly disheveled, fatigued. Behavior guarded but cooperative. Speech normal rate/volume. Mood "down and anxious"; affect constricted, tearful when recounting the event. Thought process linear; thought content notable for guilt and negative beliefs about safety; no psychosis. Cognition grossly intact though attention fluctuates. Insight and judgment fair. Suicidal ideation passive without plan/intent; denies homicidal ideation.

Overall presentation reflects persistent trauma-related re-experiencing with avoidance, negative mood/cognitions, and hyperarousal lasting >1 month with significant social and occupational impairment, along with a sustained period of depressed mood and loss of interest accompanied by neurovegetative and cognitive symptoms and passive suicidal ideation.

demographics: 32-year-old woman, married, works full-time as an elementary school teacher, lives with spouse, no children. No significant medical history; recent primary care evaluation reportedly normal (including thyroid screening). Drinks 1–2 caffeinated beverages daily, rare alcohol, denies tobacco or illicit substance use.
clinical_text:
32-year-old teacher presents for outpatient evaluation due to persistent anxiety and recent worsening mood. She reports that for approximately 9 months she has experienced excessive and hard-to-control worry occurring most days, spanning multiple areas (job performance, finances, parents’ health, and “something going wrong” during her commute). She states, “My brain doesn’t stop scanning for problems,” and “Even when nothing is happening, I’m bracing for bad news.” She describes difficulty controlling the worry, noting that reassurance provides only brief relief before she begins worrying about something else.

Associated symptoms over the same 9-month period include feeling keyed up/on edge (“I’m tense all the time”), muscle tension in her neck/shoulders with frequent headaches, irritability (“I snap at my husband over small things”), fatigue (“I feel worn out by noon”), difficulty concentrating (“I reread emails three times and still miss details”), and sleep disturbance. Sleep is described as both trouble falling asleep due to ruminative thoughts and frequent early-morning awakenings. She reports functional impact: increased time spent checking lesson plans repeatedly, avoiding taking on new responsibilities, and reduced social engagement because she feels “too anxious to be good company.”

Over the past 6 weeks, she reports a distinct downturn in mood nearly every day, most of the day, with tearfulness and a sense of hopelessness. She says, “I feel heavy and empty,” and “Nothing feels worth the effort.” She also endorses markedly diminished interest/pleasure in previously enjoyed activities such as running and meeting friends (“I keep canceling; even when I go, I don’t enjoy it”). She reports decreased appetite with an unintentional weight loss of about 6 pounds in the last month. Sleep has worsened with early-morning awakening and nonrestorative sleep. She endorses low energy nearly daily, psychomotor slowing noted by her spouse (“He says I move like I’m in slow motion”), diminished ability to think or concentrate at work (making more mistakes, taking longer to complete grading), and feelings of worthlessness/excessive guilt (“I’m letting my students down; I’m a bad partner; I can’t do anything right”).

She reports recurrent thoughts that she would be “better off not waking up,” occurring several times per week over the last month, but denies any current plan, intent, preparatory behaviors, or prior attempts. She denies homicidal thoughts. She denies any past periods of abnormally elevated or expansive mood, decreased need for sleep with increased energy, pressured speech, inflated self-esteem, or risky behavior. She denies hallucinations, paranoia, or other psychotic symptoms.

She reports that the ongoing worry and tension preceded the current low mood; she feels the constant worrying “wore me down,” and the recent depressed mood has further reduced her coping, leading to more avoidance and increased rumination. She denies that symptoms are attributable to medication, substances, or an acute medical condition. Overall, the symptoms are causing clinically significant distress and impairment in occupational performance, relationships, and self-care.
